_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


BAKER & BAKER 
ELK GROVE VILLAGE, ILLINOIS


Background Data

In accordance with Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations Chapter 68 (40 CFR 68) promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Baker & Baker submits this Risk Management Plan (RMP) for operations at their facility in Elk Grove Village, Illinois.  The operations at Baker & Baker include the manufacturing of frozen dough and bakery products for chain restaurant customers and the wholesale baking industry, packaged under various recognized brand names.  Baker & Baker has been in operation at this facility for nearly 30 years providing quality products and over 175 jobs to the local community.


Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy

Baker & Baker is committed to protecting the health of its employees, the surrounding community, and the environment.  It is Baker & Baker?s policy to maintain a safe and healthy workplace, protect the environment, and comply with all applicable regulations, including 40 CFR 68 and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration?s (OSHA?s) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation, 29 CFR 1910.119.  


Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances

To ensure the quality of Baker & Baker?s ingredients and final products, refrigeration is necessary to maintain the low temperatures required for the food processing and storage areas of the plant.  These requirements are promulgated and monitored by the United States Food and Drug Administration and the Illinois State Department of Health.  To achieve this, Baker & Baker uses anhydrous ammonia, the 112(r) regulated substance, as the primary refrigerant in the cooling system.  The ammonia refrigeration system maintains the 125,000 square-foot facility within the required range of operating temperatures and provides cooling for the manufacturing and storage of all products.  Anhydrous ammonia is a standard refrigerant for the food industries and widely used throughout the count

ry.  The refrigeration system at Baker & Baker is a closed loop system and consists of receiver vessels, compressors, evaporators, condensers, chillers, and associated piping.  The system can contain a maximum amount of approximately 12,400 pounds of anhydrous ammonia at any time during the course of the year.  Ammonia is the only regulated substance, covered by the EPA?s Chemical Accidental Prevention Provisions and the associated Risk Management Program requirements, that is used at the Elk Grove Village facility.


Worst Case and Alternative Release Scenarios

As required by 40 CFR 68 Subpart B, Baker & Baker has evaluated a worst-case release scenario for anhydrous ammonia using the parameters specified by the EPA.  The worst-case release scenario is defined as the release, over a 10-minute period, of the entire contents of the largest vessel or pipe in the facility?s system.  The worst-case release scenario was developed following EPA regulations, however, based on the facility?s operating history, it is not considered by Baker & Baker to be a likely release scenario for the facility.  A more realistic release scenario (alternative release) was developed by Baker & Baker taking into consideration the facility?s history of operational experience and the hazards identified in the process hazard analysis (PHA) conducted for the ammonia refrigeration system.  The PHA was conducted in accordance with OSHA?s Process Safety Management regulations, contained in 29 CFR 1910.119, to ensure that potential hazards are identified and evaluated to minimize the potential of occurrence.

Using the equations in Appendix E of the EPA?s General Risk Management Program Guidance document and the EPA?s RMP*Comp computer program, the maximum distances to the ?endpoint? specified for anhydrous ammonia were calculated for both scenarios and reported to the EPA.  The chemical-specific endpoints, established for release scenarios by the EPA, provide conservative estimates of the distance

s a chemical could possibly travel in the event of a release meeting the EPA?s criteria. 


Accidental Release Prevention Program

To prevent, detect, and mitigate accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia, Baker & Baker has implemented several precautionary measures including process and equipment controls, operating procedures, preventive-maintenance programs, employee training, and audit programs.  The refrigeration system was installed at the facility in 1992 and it was designed and constructed in accordance with recognized engineering and industry codes and standards. 

Baker & Baker has also developed and implemented a PSM program pursuant to OSHA regulations and as such, has evaluated the refrigeration system for the potential to release anhydrous ammonia.  Some of the controls installed to detect, prevent, or mitigate catastrophic releases of ammonia include process equipment (pressure relief valves, check valves, backup pumps, and manual shutoffs), automated controls (interlocks, automatic shutoffs, ammonia leak detection systems, and electrical distribution system grounding) and process alarms and emergency response procedures. 

Baker & Baker has developed standard operating procedures for all employees and contractors that have contact with the ammonia refrigeration system.  These procedures incorporate safety measures to prevent employee injury, equipment damage, and accidental releases.  The procedures were developed by a team consisting of personnel from operations and maintenance, plant engineering, and Baker & Baker?s refrigeration contractor.  Pursuant to written management of change procedures established by Baker & Baker, any changes to the operating procedures are to be communicated to affected employees.

Baker & Baker understands that maintaining the refrigeration system in good working order is essential to preventing accidental releases; therefore Baker & Baker has implemented a preventative maintenance program.  The preventative maintenance

program is scheduled, documented, and managed to ensure that regular maintenance occurs on the system.  Also, to ensure the mechanical integrity of critical refrigeration system components, equipment inspections are performed.

To ensure that the control measures at Baker & Baker are effective in maintaining the safe operation of the plant, regularly scheduled audits are performed on the ammonia refrigeration system and the facility, as follows:

In accordance with the OSHA and EPA requirements, Baker & Baker conducts detailed compliance audits of the Process Safety and Risk Management Programs.  Each audit incorporates a review of process safety information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, training programs, system mechanical integrity, management of change, pre-start up safety review procedures, compliance audit procedures, incident investigation procedures, employee participation programs, hot work permit procedures, and contractor safety procedures.

A third party safety consultant conducts monthly plant safety inspections and Baker & Baker?s insurance carrier performs independent loss prevention audits each year.

In addition, the facilities and/or records of Baker & Baker are inspected and audited by the following:

The Illinois State Department of Health.

The Elk Grove Village Fire Department.

The United States Food and Drug Administration.

The Cook County Department of Environmental Control.

The Metropolitan Water Reclamation District of Greater Chicago.


Five-Year Accident History

Over the last five years, Baker & Baker has not experienced any reportable releases of anhydrous ammonia from the refrigeration system.  Furthermore, there has not been a reportable release of ammonia from the system since its initial installation in late 1992. 


Emergency Response Program

The Baker & Baker facility is included in the written community emergency response plan developed for Elk Grove Village.  In addition, Baker & Baker has developed site spe

cific emergency action and emergency response plans to protect employees, the surrounding community, and the environment in the event of an ammonia release, fire, or other emergency.  These programs include the measures to be taken by Baker & Baker including emergency notifications, on-site and off-site coordination, ammonia release procedures and evacuation procedures. 

In addition, Baker & Baker has an emergency response team consisting of plant personnel trained to respond to various emergency situations including the accidental release of ammonia.  These personnel are trained in accordance with the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.120, OSHA?s Hazardous Waste Operations and Emergency Response regulations, for their response duties and functions.  Response team personnel receive initial training and annual refresher training thereafter.

To ensure that local response personnel are familiar with Baker & Baker?s facility and their emergency response procedures, tours of the facility and a copy of the facility?s Emergency Response Plan have been provided to the Elk Grove Village Fire Department.

In addition to the local fire department, Baker & Baker has arranged for emergency response assistance with two local refrigeration contractors knowledgeable in the facility layout and the design and operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.

The Baker & Baker facility is located in an industrial park covering a large portion of Elk Grove Village, and as a result, there are very few residential, community, and environmental receptors in the area.  However, in the event of an ammonia release with the potential for off-site effects, the Elk Grove Village Fire Department and the Cook County LEPC will be notified immediately.  Any notifications and/or instructions to the general public shall be made by these agencies and may include the following methods:

Police and fire vehicles equipped with public address systems, 

Door-to-door notification of residents, and

Broadcast mes

sage via the Cook County Emergency Broadcast System, if necessary.


Continuing Efforts to Improve Safety

As part of Baker & Baker?s continuous efforts to optimize the performance and safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system, several changes are planned at the facility to improve safety and further minimize the potential for ammonia releases.  These changes include process equipment upgrades, a new computer-based control system to monitor and manage the refrigeration process, and an automated condenser water treatment system.
